raw_text:
Ring of Fire hit co-writer dies
 
 Merle Kilgore, co-writer of the country hit Ring of Fire, has died of congestive heart failure aged 70.
 
 He started out as a singer and songwriter before going into music management, looking after country star Hank Williams Jr. He wrote Ring of Fire with June Carter Cash, the future wife of Johnny Cash who went on to score his most popular hit with the track. Kilgore had heart surgery in 2004 and was also diagnosed with lung cancer. His death has been attributed to treatment he was undergoing for the cancer. His first self-penned top 10 hit was Dear Mama in 1959.
 
 One of the first songs he wrote for other artists was Wolverton Mountain, which sold 10 million copies when recorded by Claude King. He then wrote Ring of Fire with June Carter Cash, which was about her unrequited love for Johnny, who she later married. It was first recorded by her younger sister Anita Carter before Johnny went on to make such a success of it. June Carter Cash previously said it upset her husband when Kilgore talked about the song without crediting her and believed he should not have been credited on it. Last year, Kilgore turned up an awards dinner in a wheelchair expecting to honour Hank Williams Jr, but instead he was the surprise recipient of a lifetime achievement award from the International Entertainment Buyers Association.
llama3.2:1b: Merle Kilgore, co-writer of Ring of Fire and singer-songwriter, died aged 70 due to congestive heart failure after being diagnosed with lung cancer in 2004.
He had also undergone heart surgery.
Kilgore wrote several songs for other artists, including the top 10 hit Dear Mama and the song Wolverton Mountain, which sold over 10 million copies.
llama3.2:3b: Merle Kilgore, co-writer of country hit Ring of Fire, has died aged 70 due to treatment for lung cancer after heart surgery in 2004.
He also wrote Dear Mama and Wolverton Mountain, among other hits, and had a strained relationship with June Carter Cash over credit for Ring of Fire.

His first song written for other artists was "Wolverton Mountain," which sold 10 million copies when recorded by Claude King.
He later wrote the hit with June Carter Cash and it featured Anita Carter as her younger sister.

He turned up at an awards dinner in a wheelchair expecting to receive a lifetime achievement award, but instead he received a lifetime achievement award from the International Entertainment Buyers Association.

tinyllama:1.1b:
Key ideas and details:
- Rapper Merle Kilgoré, who co-wrote Ring of Fire with country singer June Carter Casch and went on to become one of its biggest hitmakers, has died at age 70 due to congestive heart failure.
- Kilgoré was diagnosed with lung cancer in 2004 and was undergoing treatment for it when he passed away.
- Kilgoré's co-writer June Carter Casch also expressed regret about the credit dispute involving her husband before Kilgoré honored him at an awards ceremony.
- Kilgoré had previously been recognized with a lifetime achievement award from the International Entertainment Buyer's Association.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The death of renowned music producer Merle Kilgore has left a profound impact on country music fans and industry professionals alike.
Known for his work with acclaimed artists like Johnny Cash, June Carter Cash, and Hank Williams Jr., Kilgore's contributions to the genre have not gone unnoticed.
The cause of his death was believed to be congestive heart failure; however, he passed away at the age of 70 due to complications arising from treatment for lung cancer.
His co-written hit, "Ring of Fire," penned by June Carter Cash and Johnny Cash, became a timeless classic and has sold over 10 million copies in its initial run.
Despite his illustrious career, Kilgore's death was a great loss to his friends, family, and the music industry as a whole.
His heart was undoubtedly in the right place, and he will be remembered for his incredible work and contributions to the world of country music.

He started out as a singer and songwriter before becoming a music manager for Hank Williams Jr. Kilgore wrote Ring of Fire with June Carter Cash, who went on to marry Johnny Cash.
His first self-penned top 10 hit was "Dear Mama" in 1959.
The song Wolverton Mountain he wrote sold 10 million copies when recorded by Claude King and later became a hit for June's sister Anita.
Kilgore received an award for lifetime achievement from the International Entertainment Buyers Association but felt upset that his co-writer, June Carter Cash, was not credited on the Ring of Fire.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Merle Kilgore, co-writer of the country hit "Ring of Fire" (originally penned with June Carter Cash), died at 70 due to complications from treatment for lung cancer.

Kilgore began his career as a singer and songwriter before transitioning into music management, where he supported Hank Williams Jr. His first top-10 hit was "Dear Mama" in 1959. Notable songs he wrote include "Wolverton Mountain," which sold 10 million copies when recorded by Claude King, and "Ring of Fire."
June Carter Cash initially held concerns about Kilgore's credit for the song due to his uncredited remarks about it.

In 2022, Kilgore received a lifetime achievement award from the International Entertainment Buyers Association at an event where he was expected to honor Williams Jr., despite appearing in a wheelchair.
